This is a re-run.
Greece is in very dire straits. So, they accept the austerity they vehemently denied they'd ever accept....but they get some money and get some of their debt forgiven, a lower interest rate, and longer term (in other words, what they got in 2012 with 53% written off, lower rate, double the loan term).

Then, when payment is due, they will not be able to pay because they are - and will remain - broke. This is because of a simple issue - they dole out more cash than they take in. Period.

So, when it is clear they cannot repay, they will - us, you guessed it - claim greedy bankers gave them loans that were overboard and therefore should be forgiven, and, over, and over again.

Except this time, they have the readers here thinking it's all Germany's fault.

Barnum was right.

Speaking of the bottling of beverages:

In my one college bio course, we did lab work involving yeast. Of course, that meant making BEER. Our TF said she would provide caps and do the capping if some of us would bring in bottles before the beer was finished. As was the style at the time, my roommates and I typically had a few empties laying about, so I rinsed them and brought them to her office. Elke, most likely they were Molson or Heineken.

I advised the Teaching Fellow that I did not plan on taking home that much BEER; I just wanted her to have enough bottles to go around. (Crush? Slight.)

She thanked me and confided that she had gotten plenty of bottles -- but most were unusable because so many students had brought in bottles that use twist-off caps. (The capping device only worked on the other kind of bottle.)

I'm not sure whether the thinly-veiled disgust in her tone resulted from being presented with unusable bottles, or from the fact that so many of her undergrads were drinking American BEER. (She was European.)

The "BEEROCLOCK" business reminded me of earlier days when a case of beer contained 24 cans. Someone older than I once explained that since there are 24 hours in a day, it makes perfect sense and simplifies everything.

Shoshon:

Forgive me, but your response makes no sense. While the U.S. is hardly guiltless of living beyond our means, our governance is the most transparent in the world. We know what that picture looks like, but the political and human costs of actually painting it is so high that we've only begun to fight about it.

But knowing what it must look like when actually painted must be the first step to BEGINNING to properly fight about it; and Greece isn't yet even at THAT point.

Crusader:

You miss the point. If Europe were convinced that Greece were sound and sustainable if only they wiped out a debt that now is owed almost entirely to governments and government-like entities, they'd likely just write it off. The problem is that they're convinced that writing it off simply means that the subsidies would continue, likely forever, because in that eventuality Greece would do nothing to change the reasons for its lack of strategic economic viability.

The states of Europe are far too focused on paying for their OWN socialisms, which they're doing despite dangerous pressures and signs of difficulty (including high unemployment, particularly among their young, and powerlessness in the face of Russian aggression depending as they do on the U.S. for real defense), to entertain the notion of forever paying for someone else's.
The dystopian surreality of Merkel/Germany's view of the Greek debt conundrum would not be complete without a Luettgen homily

What Tsipras SHOULD have been asked to develop and provide for general review, MONTHS ago, was a picture of Greek governance that was sustainable: the percentage of the labor force that was employed by the public sector, the end-state labor protections after reforming legislation, the percentage of GDP dedicated to pensions and the whole social safety net (and how it would be paid for), the MEANS by which taxes would be honestly collected, how he intended to massively cut the bureaucracy that stifles every commercial transaction, and a point-by-point response to detailed charges of general corruption and a description of how it would be rooted-out.

Such a picture, plus an actionable plan to paint it, would have done far more to establishing the expectation that their newest request for 53.5 billion euros actually will result in stability, instead of three more years of mere can-kicking.

You said it. Exactly. After all their chest pounding contrition over their earlier wille zur macht manifestations, they feel entirely comfortable economically hobbling their neighbor for generations to come.

Yes Greece had mismanaged its economy, but given its history on the receiving end of forgiveness (not only debts, but lots of other stuff), the draconian moral high horse ill suits the German regime. Let them consult Shakespeare's "Measure for Measure" for an assessment of such a posture, or for that matter Shakespeare's character Shylock, whom, judging from history, many Germans would not want to resemble. Yet a whole lot more than a pound of flesh is what they seek.

In a word: Greece will be paralyzed for a generation. Don't go there and breed the kind of repercussions that would be sure to follow. Germany of all nations should know what can fester in an economically crushed society.

The economic situation in Greece must be more dire than anyone has thus far admitted. The Greek government (which will surely soon collapse) presumably decided that caving in to demands for even more damaging austerity is the only alternative to economic implosion.

Meanwhile, the German bankers are surely reveling in sadistic Schadenfreude at the prospect of inflicting even more austerity on the Greeks. It doesn't matter that austerity will only guarantee that Greece will never have an economy strong enough to repay its debt. (The Germans presumably learned that lesson after World War I.) It's no longer about debt or economics. The Greeks need to be punished severely for their inexcusable defiance!

First they elected an unacceptable leftist government that dared to challenge the Sacred Austerity decreed from On High. And then they committed insubordination by voting against a undeservedly merciful bailout.

Ja! A generation of suffering under maximum austerity should instill proper humility and respect for the sovereignty and superiority of their German creditor-overlords. Perhaps the next generation, who grew up under austerity, will have learned not only correct subservient Respect for their Superiors, but Responsibility. Perhaps then, under a suitably tight leash (periodically jerked with enough Tough Love to ensure humility and respect), the wise German bankers will guide Greece into a new fiscal era.

But for now, Let There Be Austerity!

"Debt relief?"

That term appears to mean different things to different people. "Debt relief" typically means one or more of three things:

1. A reduction of principal.
2. A reduced interest rate.
3. A stretched-out payment schedule.

The article says Merkel still says "no" to #1, but is less clear about #2 and #3. Many Greece supporters, on the other hand, equate "debt relief" with #1. If a deal gets done, I suspect we'll see all three, but more of #2 and #3 than #1.

Speaking of "debt relief," what about the few Greek-debt holders who are not the ECB, Eurozone countries, or the IMF – i.e. the hedge-fund gunslingers? Do the big 3 have the power to force "debt relief" on them (e.g. by a majority-in-interest vote of the debt holders), or will they get carved out and paid in full? I don't know, but I'll wager this with great confidence:

If the Greek bonds give the majority-in-interest holders authority to force "debt relief" on all holders, that's what they'll do. If they don't, the hedge-fund gunslingers will get carved out and paid in full.

Another thing for sure: Those hedge-fund gunslingers (or their lawyers) know what the answer to that question is, and they knew that answer before they decided to buy up that cheap Greek debt at pennies on the dollar.

Austerity imposed again? Sure hope much of the debt is forgiven. Otherwise, how is the Greek economy possibly going to recover?

To quote from Simon Wren-Lewis,
"That the Greek economy now lies broken is not the inevitable result of imprudent borrowing a decade ago, or structural weaknesses, or a left wing government elected just a few months ago. It is also the result of the actions of those who effectively ran the economy from 2010 to 2014, and their imposition of draconian austerity. Greece long ago recognised the folly of its borrowing, and has made a start on addressing its structural weaknesses. The Troika has yet to acknowledge its own part in making this tragedy."
